UK 84, North Carolina 70: What we learned

Takeaways from the Wildcats' win over the Tar Heels

UK's Alex Poythress tears ACL, season over

UK 84, North Carolina 70: What we learned

Adam Himmelsbach

Adam Himmelsbach, ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com 4:14 p.m. EST December 13, 2014

Kentucky basketball players react during their win over North Carolina on Saturday.(Photo: Scott Utterback)

Tags

  • GameHQKentucky
  • University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
  • Alex Poythress
  • NBA Draft
  • Trey Lyles
1 CONNECT 10 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Here's what we learned in the University of Kentucky's 84-70 victory over North Carolina at Rupp Arena on Saturday

Kentucky might get up for big games: This is a pretty stunning stat: In the first halves against Buffalo and Columbia this season, the Wildcats were outscored by a total of 63-56. In the first halves against Kansas and North Carolina this season, the Wildcats outscored those teams 87-62.

Speaking of the UNC and Kansas games: The Kentucky basketball team outscored Kansas and North Carolina by a total score of 156-110. Think about that for a second.

GAME REWIND: Look back at Wildcats' win over the Tar Heels

RECAP: Top-ranked Wildcats blast No. 21 North Carolina 84-70

The platoon system is still alive, sort of: Alex Poythress' injury was certain to affect the 10-man platoon system in some fashion. Less than four minutes into the game, Calipari inserted four new players, leaving in Trey Lyles, who had previously been a member of that second group. After that, though, a more regular substitution pattern emerged.

When this team makes 3-pointers, it will not lose: It might not lose regardless, but it really won't lose when it makes 3-pointers. The Wildcats had a total of six made 3-pointers in their last three games. They equaled that number in the first half on Saturday and finished by going 7-for-15. UK shot 56 percent from the floor overall. That'll do it.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Alex Poythress honored by Kentucky basketball players with #RoarFor22 shirts

The Wildcats are happy to run-and-gun, but they have to get back on defense: In the first half on Saturday, North Carolina beat UK downcourt in transition for several easy baskets. The Wildcats seemed to rectify the situation as the game went on, but given the glut of ready subs, Calipari will probably not stand for any defensive lapses.

Yes, the Wildcats miss Alex Poythress, but they'll be fine: More than anything, the junior forward's season-ending ACL tear will take an emotional toll on this squad. Yes, they will miss his rebounding, defense and athleticism. But let's face it, this team is ridiculously deep and talented and is probably the only team in the country that can overcome the loss of a future NBA draft pick without missing much of a beat.

UK Coach John Calipari talks about 84-70 win over North Carolina. Matt Stone, The C-J

We should enjoy these games while we can: After UK faces U of L on Dec. 27, there is a possibility the Wildcats will not face another ranked team until the postseason. No other SEC teams are currently ranked—though one or two will probably rejoin the polls at some point simply because the conference wins will have to come from somewhere. Regardless, especially with Florida's struggles, the league is going to be pretty terrible.

Speaking of the Cardinals: Sure, UK will probably have a road game or two in which it is tested, but there is a real possibility the Dec. 27 game at the Yum! Center is the last real threat to UK's perfect regular season.

If you want something to nitpick: North Carolina did out-rebound UK, 31-24, not that it really mattered.

Tyler Ulis is the heartbeat: The offense just runs more smoothly when the freshman point guard is in the game. Midway through the second half, after UNC had sliced the deficit to nine, Ulis carved through the lane on back-to-back plays and found teammates for easy baskets, the second being an artful alley-oop to Willie Cauley-Stein. Ulis needs to play more than 18 minutes per game. I think he's the most important player on this team.

Devin Booker had a day: The freshman made all three of his 3-point attempts and finished with a team-high 15 points.
